text:
When we let programmers structure the world through code, the strictures of the code's language frame what's possible, and therefore also the world they create and impose upon us

<https://twitter.com/laurencediver/status/1468145966347923456|https://twitter.com/laurencediver/status/1468145966347923456>

text: That reminds me of a link I've been meaning to share: <http://opentranscripts.org/transcript/programming-forgetting-new-hacker-ethic/>

attachments.title: Programming is Forgetting: Toward a New Hacker Ethic - Allison Parrish | Open Transcripts
attachments.text: I wouldn't be surprised to find out that many of us here today like to see our work as a continuation of say the Tech Model Railroad Club or the Homebrew Computer Club, and certainly the terminology and the values of this conference, like open source for example, have their roots in that era. As a consequence it's easy to interpret any criticism of the hacker ethic—which is what I'm about to do—as a kind of assault.
attachments.fallback: Open Transcripts: Programming is Forgetting: Toward a New Hacker Ethic - Allison Parrish | Open Transcripts

elements.text: That reminds me of a link I've been meaning to share:

text: Tbh, I don't think the problem with programmers structuring the world is the programming languages they use! :blush:

elements.text: Tbh, I don't think the problem with programmers structuring the world is the programming languages they use!

text: The author working in "computational law", I guess he considers any programming language (perhaps even any formal language) too constraining for structuring the world. And with that I'd agree.

elements.text: The author working in "computational law", I guess he considers any programming language (perhaps even any formal language) too constraining for structuring the world. And with that I'd agree.

text:
Yeah, definitely not the only problem. But a small problem that is part of this larger problem. 

Imagine if for example McCarthy's elephant 2000 existed. Now we have a language involving speech acts. A different conceptual framework than I think many of us programmers are familiar with.

As we structure the world more and more through code, we do have to ask what sorts of assumptions are pre-baked into our languages. What things are easy to express? What things are hard? Does that fact that most of our programming languages today are fairly similar have any impact on that?

elements.text:
Yeah, definitely not the only problem. But a small problem that is part of this larger problem. 

Imagine if for example McCarthy's elephant 2000 existed. Now we have a language involving speech acts. A different conceptual framework than I think many of us programmers are familiar with.

As we structure the world more and more through code, we do have to ask what sorts of assumptions are pre-baked into our languages. What things are easy to express? What things are hard? Does that fact that most of our programming languages today are fairly similar have any impact on that?

text:
The languages are rarely the problem (unless we go Sapir-Whorf here), but the problem is the models we express in those language and how we stick to them or not.

Put differently, the problem is not that your language has Booleans, it's when you use Boolean to model gender when you create a problem.

elements.text:
The languages are rarely the problem (unless we go Sapir-Whorf here), but the problem is the models we express in those language and how we stick to them or not.

Put differently, the problem is not that your language has Booleans, it's when you use Boolean to model gender when you create a problem.

text: Exactly. Inappropriate and/or premature formalization. Which happens not only in code. The numerical targets so loved by managers are quite similar.

elements.text: Exactly. Inappropriate and/or premature formalization. Which happens not only in code. The numerical targets so loved by managers are quite similar.

text:
Completely agree that models are the problem. I do think I'd just add to that that what models are easy or difficult to work with and express depends on our language. 

Simple examples, Nats vs u32 vs integer vs floats. Some problems are better modeled with these various types. But it I'm in J's I'm probably modeling them with floats (the only real number type).

How many things do we not do or choose to not even consider because our languages make it difficult to express?

elements.text:

Simple examples, Nats vs u32 vs integer vs floats. Some problems are better modeled with these various types. But it I'm in J's I'm probably modeling them with floats (the only real number type).

How many things do we not do or choose to not even consider because our languages make it difficult to express?

text: If we compare computing systems to the actual concepts of language (natural) and writing, we can immediately see the shortcoming of talking solely about "programming languages"

elements.text: If we compare computing systems to the actual concepts of language (natural) and writing, we can immediately see the shortcoming of talking solely about "programming languages"

text: Programming "languages" are not very good on their own and lack the most important feature of true natural language, which is that you get it for free no matter what

elements.text: Programming "languages" are not very good on their own and lack the most important feature of true natural language, which is that you get it for free no matter what

text: In this sense, programming languages are more like writing, which has to be learned over a sustained period of time, and which is the symbolic representation of language and linguistic thought.

elements.text: In this sense, programming languages are more like writing, which has to be learned over a sustained period of time, and which is the symbolic representation of language and linguistic thought.

text: All of this exists within an environment that gives it context and which enables its use, in standard or novel ways

elements.text: All of this exists within an environment that gives it context and which enables its use, in standard or novel ways

text: What I'm saying is that it's not enough to talk of programming languages on their own. It will get you nowhere. You have to talk about computing environments

elements.text: What I'm saying is that it's not enough to talk of programming languages on their own. It will get you nowhere. You have to talk about computing environments

text: Doing most of your computing in a system that still uses a teletype metaphor at its core is going to be more restrictive to your potential mental models than whether or not language X uses floats as its number type

elements.text: Doing most of your computing in a system that still uses a teletype metaphor at its core is going to be more restrictive to your potential mental models than whether or not language X uses floats as its number type

The Abstract is ‘an Enemy’
